title: Classic English Country House With Pool and Croquet Lawn Asks £2M
text:
This former rectory is more than 300 years old.

Text size

A more than 300-year-old former rectory in the village of Hurstpierpoint in the south of England hit the market Monday asking £2 million (US$2.59 million).

Aptly named Church House—the rectory was the home provided to the vicar or priest of the church next door—the red tile and brick building dates to 1690 and is Grade II listed.

More: Empty Mansion Up For Sale in Posh London Neighborhood

The current owners, who bought the home in 2009, embarked on an extensive refurbishment and remodelling while working “carefully and sensitively with the property's listed status,” according to the listing with Savills.

Mansion Global couldn’t identify the identity of the owners, or how much they paid for the home.

A Grade II-listed property is legally protected for being of special architectural and historic interest. The designation restricts the work that can be done on a home and owners must maintain their home’s historic value whenever they renovate.

The resulting 3,722-square-foot home has classic features like wood-burning stoves and fireplaces, exposed timbers and sash windows combined with more contemporary additions, such as under-floor heating, modern bathroom suites and a bespoke hand-built kitchen, according to the listing.

“This beautiful house is one of the best in Hurstpierpoint,” said listing agent Rohan Vines in a statement. “It’s easy to imagine sitting by the pool in the summer months enjoying the wonderful views to the South Downs [National Park], or cozying up by the roaring inglenook fire in the colder weather.”

The home’s five bedrooms are spread across the top two floors of the four-story house, and include a master bedroom with a curved ceiling, the listing said.

Outside, on the more than half-acre grounds are rose beds, a kitchen garden with raised beds, a swimming pool, a croquet lawn and a brick potting shed.

This article originally appeared on Mansion Global .
